course.subject: ENGG
course.name: Engineering Solutions to Grand Challenges of the 21st Century
course.description: Throughout human history, engineering has driven the advance of civilization. In the past century engineering has recorded its greatest accomplishments, but for all these accomplishments the century ahead poses formidable problems sustaining civilization advancement. This course will broaden and raise student's awareness of challenges faced by coming generations such as climate change, clean water and healthcare. Students will work in small groups in a collaborative learning environment to explore in details and in multiple dimensions the key issues around selected major challenges with experts in the areas. Suggested and proposed engineering solutions based on advances in science and technology will be explored and discussed. Students will be encouraged to develop and present their own innovative engineering approaches to address these major challenges.

reviews.author: Alicia
reviews.comment_content: Content was about engineering challenges, especially in personalized learning and renewable energy. Your challenges may not be the same ones. The class is structured in group projects/papers and presentations, there are no exams.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lectures some days, but the professor tries to let you work in groups with the TAs for the majority of class meetings.
reviews.comment_grading: There were rubrics for each assignment, so grading was fairly transparent. Group members also rate each other on how well they work together and some other metrics.
reviews.comment_workload: Not too bad until you get closer to the project due dates, you will probably need to coordinate with your group to work on finishing and handing in the reports.

reviews.author: Szeto
reviews.title: Light Workload but you dont learn anything
reviews.comment_content:
Honestly I dont know what I learnt throughout the course. There is a total of 2 projects that I mentioned in the workload. See the official content below:

Students who take this course will be exposed to examples of the major challenges of the 21st century and the issues involved. By working in teams, they will explore various approaches that are or have been proposed around the world to address or attempt to tackle these problems. By completing the course, students will be able to:
1. Identify the key issues involved in two real-world engineering problems by obtaining information from experts and the literature. (Intended Learning Outcome, ILO, #1)
2. Analyze these problems from multiple dimensions and angles including feasibility, scalability, and sustainability. (ILO #2)
3. Suggest and evaluate solutions to these problems by working collaboratively. (ILO #3)
4. Present and defend their solutions orally and in writing. (ILO #4)
reviews.comment_teaching: Close to no teaching in the course. Mainly is about group discussing about the project. Failed to realise the potential of the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Average grading. Attached is the Syllabus but it is not accurate. Most of my groupmates got B which is ok considering the effort and the amount of time they were able to dedicate. I'm sure you will also get a good grade. Just put in some extra effort if needed.

Grading will be based on your project grade as well as participation in discussions and peer review. Your final project grade will be determined by three factors.
reviews.comment_workload:
Easy workload. As mentioned there are only 2 projects so it depends if you have good groupmates. You just need to create 2 separate projects which has a presentation and question you have to prepare to ask the other groups, but overall it's not too hard.

For the 1st project, there is only 1 week to prepare which is about the pandemic; the 2nd project is about a grand challenge to solve using AI. You'll have 2 weeks to prepare for the 2nd project. The final presentation is under 8 minutes.

reviews.author: sleepy0527
reviews.title: easy A range (FIND GOOD TEAMMATES)
reviews.comment_content:
The content is about modern global issues. I don't know if it changes from time to time but for my semester, it is about megacities and pandemics.

Lectures mainly focused on guiding you to think about the issues from different perspectives and you needed to work and discuss with your teammates every lecture about the mini-tasks given by the prof.

The overall content was quite easy to understand as it was basically about the current world problems. And the prof would talk about them in detail so there's no need to worry about the content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In every lecture, the professors normally introduced the topics first. And then they gave you lots of time to discuss with your teammates and sometimes needed to do a short report to the whole class.

The prof and TAs responded to questions very quickly and gave you clear instructions on what to do in the lectures and presentations and final reports.

You spent most of the time with your teammates so make sure they are responsible and show up at every lecture. The TAs would ask you to find them if they don't show up.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class assessment 20%
Presentation on the 1st challenge 20%
Presentation on the 2nd challenge 15%
Written report on the 2nd challenge 15%
Role Play on Global Perspectives 10%
Teamwork (peer evaluation) / individual contributions 20%

Grading really depends on your group rather than yourself.
So just make sure you find someone or your friends who care about grades.

Above mean in most grading criteria
Final grade A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Not heavy at all. (only if you got normal teammates)
Important info all given in lectures.
Just need to spend a little time doing research on the presentations. (you can do this during the group discussion time)
Division of work !!!!! It really saved me a lot of time.
Little time on practicing the presentation.
Little time on final reports.
Be careful that the presentations are near the mid-term and final periods. So make sure your group finishes everything before mid-term and final.

reviews.author: Shady
reviews.title: Very Good Common Core course
reviews.comment_content:
The content is reasonable for a common core course.

There are 2 parts to it or 2 'challenges'

The first challenge is the issues faced by megacities

The second challenge is the threat posed by pandemics
reviews.comment_teaching: The professors and TAs are very good. They are very responsive to questions asked in class. They are also open to discussion and encourage exchange of different perspectives.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is exemplary

It is also quite diverse. There are many components to this course.

First Presentation for First Challenge: 20%
Reflective Statement for First Challenge : 5%
Second Presentation for Second Challenge : 15%
Final Report for Second Challenge : 15%
Roleplay : 10%
Individual Portfolio : 10%
Class Participation : 5%
Peer Evaluation : 20%

Final Grade : A+
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 2 presentations, both of which require extensive preparation.
The final report is the most time consuming as it is 20 pages long.
There is also a role play.

These 4 items are team based

Besides this, there is an individual reflective statement for the first part of the course and there is also an individualised final portfolio which we need to upload.

So yes, the workload can be considered quite heavy

reviews.author: plfung
reviews.comment_content: The course will consist of several components and delivery mechanisms. Lectures and tutorials will be used in a collaborative learning format, with students working in teams.Two engineering grand challenges will be presented by two experts in the relevant field.Resources will be provided to the teams to assist them in the learning environment and in the technical details.Tutorials  will  be  conducted  in  a  manner  to  guide  the  student  teams in  exploring  the engineering solutions  to  the challenges  presented.Resources  will  be  provided  to  the  teams  to  assist  them  in  the learning environment and in the technical details.Each team will submit a project report to one of the challenges.
reviews.comment_teaching: We will have group discussion mostly in the class so the professor and TAs did not do a lot of talking. They just gave us some background information of the challenges and guide us to think critically.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class assessment(Breakout findings/Screenshots portfolio): 20%
Presentation on the 1st challenge: 20%
Presentation on the 2nd challenge+ Role play:25%
Written report on the 2nd challenge: 15%
Teamwork(ipeer)/ individual contributions: 20%
The prof will randomly assign group mates so the grading is based on your effort on the project and the quality of your teammates. I was lucky to have thoughtful teammates who can contribute a lot. At the end, I got an A+ (2nd highest mark in 1st presentation, highest mark in 2nd presentation, final report slightly below mean).
reviews.comment_workload:
Acceptable workload.
But if you aim for a better grade, better focus more on the presentation and written report.

reviews.author: Stellar123
reviews.comment_content: Various grand challenges, their solutions, and approaches to derive solutions to solve grand challenges, with some in class debates and sometimes talks by experts in various engineering fields.   Not sure if challenges covered differs each semester though.  For presentations and projects, we have megacities as our first challenge and water scarcity as our second challenge this semester.  You donâ€™t need to be an engineering student to understand the content.
reviews.comment_teaching: The grand challenge content itself is easy to follow and understand.
reviews.comment_grading: You need some luck for this as you canâ€™t choose your own group mates.
reviews.comment_workload:
Various graded and ungraded in-class assignments, 2 presentations (1st and 2nd challenge), group report (2nd challenge), ipeer (1st and 2nd challenge, including self evaluation), screenshot portfolio (3 screenshots of moments during completion of in class assignments throughout the semester and a reflection of not more then 300 words with reference to those screenshots), role play (our theme is creating a survival plan in Mars in a Mars base)
Workload is heavy only when the project and presentations deadlines are near.

reviews.author: Acye
reviews.comment_content: This course teaches about sustainable energy and resources, and Virtual reality. Actually, in this course, there are very fewer contents learning. You should look at the paper and find a way to solve the resource problem and application for the Virtual reality.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is good. During the group conversation with groupmate, professor and TA try to join the group and find the solution and lead the way to get a better result.
reviews.comment_grading:
I am not sure about the grading. Professors say that the grading is absolute so that the teams are not competing for each other. However, it is quite difficult to get a good grade. If you do not know about the citation, writing reports and presentation, I prefer not to take this course.

The group presentation, reports and making prototype are included in your grading. Also, your grade would be good or bad depending on our group mate.
Every end of the projects each group members will grade their teammate. I think those grading would affect teamwork and individual working mark. So in order to get a good mark in this course, you must do all of your work and be a good member of a group

The gradings are distributed by:
1. Progress Presentationon the 1st challenge - 5%
2. Written report on the 1st challenge - 25%
3. Prototype demonstrationon the 2nd challenge - 10%
4. Oral presentation on 2ndchallenge - 15%
5. Written report on the 2nd challenge - 25%
6. Individual work on the challenges - 10%
7. Teamwork on the challenges - 10%
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite a lot. During the normal day, there is no workload to do. However, if the assignments are given, then you have a lot of things to do until the deadline.

reviews.author: kahei
reviews.title: Interesting topic but unclear instructions
reviews.comment_content:
The lectures were mainly separated into two topics: Sustainable development and Virtual Reality. (Not sure if the topics change in the future)
The content taught in the lectures was mainly basic backgrounds information which was not really helpful for the projects so you can use your laptop in class to do something else. There were TAs assigned to each group to help you out with the group projects, do ask them questions and discuss with them, they are kind and really helpful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Pong is a passionate professor and most of the TAs are friendly and helpful but I think the instruction and standards for the projects were unclear, we got different instructions and suggestions from different TAs and the professor which made us so confused during the project.

Although the professor is very passionate, the content he taught is more or less "useless", you don't have to pay attention to the lectures as the content doesn't really help you to finish your project.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading overall is good, it is very easy to get a B range or above.

Even within a group, each of you will get different scores in the group project as you need to specify which part of the project was completed by you so you need to make sure you did a great job in your part.

Although the syllabus stated that attendance is not counted but there is an attendance sheet that you need to sign every lesson.
reviews.comment_workload:
There were no exams or assignments, but there are two projects each of them with one draft report, a final report. Also for the first project, you only need to do a short progress presentation but for the second project, you need to do a progress presentation, a prototype demonstration, and a final presentation.

There are only a few lessons before you hand in your first draft report. After you hand in your final report for the first project, the second project starts immediately which is quite a lot to do although there are no exams.

reviews.author: bbmadevipalive
reviews.title: Interesting topics but useless lectures
reviews.comment_content:
First challenge: environmental conservation on campus
Second challenge: Technology and application of VR and/or AR
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture contents are mainly useless, esp the last lesson as it was just a course evaluation with snacks. Insufficient time given in lectures for group discussion so more meetings were needed outside class. Just follow the requirements and comments of TAs to get high marks though many of those were dmanding. Just show you have put effort on it!!
reviews.comment_grading:
the marks have little deviation
we got the highest mark on first report but an acceptable mark for second report. We scored well in second group presentation, probably one of the highest. And scores obtained in other areas are soso.
Got an A-. Fairly good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Tons of workload!!!!! Freeriders were present but we managed to get over it!!
For both challenges:
Individual literature reviews
Progress presentations
Final reports
For second challenge only:
Prototype
Final presentation

reviews.author: Radhika
reviews.title: Good grading if you got hard working group mates
reviews.comment_content: Content is to solve the engineering challenges in the field of personalized learning and renewable energy. The challenges may differ from group to group. The class is structured in group reports and presentations, there are no exams and no quizzes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is fine but we already know about half of the stuff talked about in class so it becomes a bit boring. Since there aren't any quizzes, you don't need to focus much on class and you can work on your laptops. And each group is assigned a TA and they are very helpful, so you can even ask them to proofread your reports before submission, this is the best method to score high in this course!
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fare actually, as I said if you got if you got smart and hardworking group mates you will be able to do well in this course as its all about group projects and this is also one of the reasons I managed an A. Also, the course outline doesn't show that your class attendance is included, but they do maintain an attendance record to check which group members skipped classes the most and didn't contribute much to in-class discussions, so try not to miss too many lectures and try to maintain a score above mean in all the assignments and B+ is yours.
reviews.comment_workload: 2 reports, 2 drafts, 1 big presentation and 2 mini presentations, although seems like a lot of work, is group work and hence manageable and most of the class time is for group discussions only.  A drawback is that you can't choose your own group, so it is like you are relying on your luck here if you got smart and hardworking group mates you will be able to do well.

reviews.author: international
reviews.comment_content: Learn about grand challenges, sustainability, MOOCs.
reviews.comment_teaching: The material in lectures is not essential to the project but may be helpful for students that do not have any background on the topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is easy if you do your part in the project and discussions.

Contributed to class discussions, did my parts of the project well and efficiently, gave many ideas for potential solutions to the project problems.

If you do your part of the project distribution you are going to get good review from your peers and you will most likely get a good grade overall.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is considerably lighter than other common cores.

No exam, 2 projects and 1-2 presentations.

If the workload in the group projects is distributed accordingly the workload is very light.

reviews.author: Aashi
reviews.comment_content: Quite mediocre however, the professor makes a strong effort to keep things interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: You can get bored easily however, luckily, there is no quiz so there isnt that much of a need to pay close attention. You can work side by side on your laptops while listening to him and there will not be a problem.
reviews.comment_grading: He is pretty fair in terms of grading
reviews.comment_workload: 2 reports, 2 drafts, 1 big presentation and 2 mini presentations. Sounds like a lot, however, it is all group work and therefore should be manageable. A downside though is that you cannot choose your own groups.

reviews.author: Nathan
reviews.comment_content: The content is just right for someone who interested in engineering world
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching gives adequate of teaching material, where the instructor put all of the lecture notes on the canvas. However, the instructor does not gives clear instruction on how and what does (s)he wants.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is just adequate. The grading system is divided into two part: peer grading, where your fellow friend gives comment and grades to your performance; and tutor grading, where your team's tutor gives the grading, comment, and also what you are lacking of.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is depend on how your team works and how you can contribute to your group.

reviews.author: PopP
reviews.title: Short Summary Review
reviews.comment_content: This course provides an introduction to some innovative inventions and encourages students to participate in solving some 'grand challenges' Overall this course does not only revolve around engineering solutions on some boring problems but instead on some interesting daily-life problems such as e-learning.
reviews.comment_teaching: Interactive teaching style; students are arranged into groups and will sit according to that group during lesson. There will be group discussions and activities throughout every single lecture (except presentation classes) Two small groups will then be merged into a large group for the final project.
reviews.comment_grading: Two main projects throughout the course. Grading mainly on the reports of the two projects and class participation.
reviews.comment_workload: No midterm or final, great relief. Just projects and class participation (though i haven't answered anything during class though)

reviews.author: Morris
reviews.comment_content:
The content varies depends on the guest that the course are able to invite regarding to the topic. In my case, it is the the former chairman of HK electric for the topic of HK electricity mix and a professor in UST for the food waste problem in HK.

The first few lectures will be about the idea of the course, then it would be the topic introduction, followed by some free consultation class then, move on to the next topic, and then final presentation.

It is not the content, but the way of finding solutions from a team collaboration. If you are expecting hard knowledge instead of vague mindset, this might not be the right course for you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching style is not for every one. It was in a room full of moving furnitures. Professor will lead the discussion, but mostly from respond to students opinion on a certain subject.

Another great part of learning comes form peer learning, where each group would be assigned with students from different schools and majors. Through the experience I find myself think different at times when communicating with students from different majors. That being said, the situation of free riders seems to be higher than other average course.

The grouping are usually 5- 6 people, depending on the enrollment of students from different major.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is fair. Mostly depends on the two reports and the presentation.

Another part is class participation and the teamwork of the group.
reviews.comment_workload: The heaviest workload of the course is the two project and the presentation. The project reports could be as long as 30 - 40 page. The presentation is less demanding compared to some other business presentation course in contrast.

reviews.author: kchanah
reviews.title: ENGG1110 Review
reviews.comment_content: I'm not sure there's much 'learning' value in the course. The topic revolves around engineering challenges and problem solving techniques. Nothing taught in class is particularly relevant for the projects or are relevant but so basic that you could learn the same via Wikipedia. Note taking is unnecessary. With that said, I would still recommend going to class anyways because its an opportunity for you to discuss your project with your group mates; it's hard to find a collective meeting time for a group of 4 (and even harder when that group expands to 9). Attendance is taken at the beginning of the class but there are no participation points; TC encourages active participation although he is often ignored. I think he still takes attendance points into account when he gives out your final grade, especially if a lot of people score high. I would therefore recommend going to class and bring a fully charged laptop (so you can zone out and do something so as to not waste your time).
reviews.comment_teaching:
TC and the respective TAs are very enthusiastic and nice. Honestly I didn't expect them to put in so much effort with teaching and making games. They hand out worksheets to assist brainstorming. It's kind of like primary school to be honest. The activities leading up to your project seem really unnecessary and childish but can be quite interesting. It's a nice change from the usual high-stress UST environment.

Each group is assigned a TA. We had 3 TAs and a lot of past student helpers. They served to guide us through our brainstorming and often participated in our discussions as well. It really helped clarify what the professor wanted and expected from us.
reviews.comment_grading:
Project Report 1 25%
Project Report 2 25%
Final Report Presentation 30%
Teamwork 20%

Fair grading. The typical grading system applies.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is adequate - there's no homework and no revision is necessary. Workload is only heavy when you write your progress report, draft and final report. The progress report is a 2 slide PPT that displays your problem statement and your solution. It's followed by a 3 minute presentation and 2 minute Q&A. Both of which are not marked. The draft report is 5 pages and consists of basic elements of your final report; this is also not graded. The final report must be within 20 pages. All guidelines and criteria are clearly listed in the syllabus. The final presentation applies to the last engineering challenge. It's a group presentation but it's not necessary for all group members to go up and speak; our group had 3 native speakers present.

reviews.author: ooj
reviews.title: I meant to post this for engg1100... oops
reviews.comment_content:
This is a hard course to write about, and an even harder course to consider taking, since THEY DO SOMETHING DIFFERENT EVERY YEAR/SEM?? Just check the reviews! One year, they do flying drones, one year, they do blender, one year, they do race cars, etc etc...

Anyways, for us, we had to make 3(+1 backup) football robots, each with a kicking mechanism and 3 omniwheels, with an Arduino that connects to your Android app using Bluetooth. From this course, you will (or should) learn Arduino, Android MIT App Inventor, some basic electronics, and 3d modelling. Sounds fun, right? Hell no. Just read the rest of this review or any other one to find out why.

One thing is for certain, if we did not have access to the labs 24/7, we would be SCREWED. Especially with HK MAYBE shutting down soon, please please please keep in mind that this course will probably bum you hard if you do it online! Only take it if you are sure you are willing to carry your team or will do it with friends.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Simple. They do not. I wish I was joking, I really do. They do not teach you anything. They give you some basic information using HKMOOC which is some sort of online learning platform where you're forced to watch overly long videos about something or the other, and then when you actually need to build your robots... You will end up using 33% asking an STA, 33% Google, 33% trial and error, and 1% giving up and trying something else.

Have fun lol
reviews.comment_grading:
Individual (30%) work:
HKMOOC - 5%
Launch Level Demo - 10%
Robot Design - 5%
Kicking Mechanism Design Sketch - 5%
Attendance for Build Sessions - 5%

Team (70%) work:
First Build Demo - 15%
Final Competition Part 1 (Dribble/Shoot) - 20%
Final Competition Part 2 (Football Match) - 25%
Team Logo/Uniform - 10%

Upon first glance, the grading may seem quite fair for a project course. HOWEVER, the biggest problem is that any idiot with more than 2 braincells will be able to 100% the individual section. Furthermore, any team with more than 4 collective braincells will be able to 100% everything EXCEPT the final competition. The STAs (who grade you) are trying to be nice and generous, but that leads to everything - almost your entire grade - coming down to one lesson, and in our case, a final football match and competition we only did well in thanks to luck. For context, our robots were basically trashcans with wheels, with cardboard torn up and taped onto them, and only won because we cheesed our 'kicking mechanism' to be sticks coming out of the robot (they didn't even move).

(Also, not to mention, initially, part 1 of the final competition had all 3 of your robots placed on a table styled like a football pitch and they had to pass and dribble through a specified path to score a goal. Initially, there were lots of sharp turns and corners but since it was too hard, they made it a straight line LMAO so everyone aced it.)

Essentially, your final grade was determined by how you did in the final football match, which was... essentially luck. Your teammates control the robots, but that doesn't mean anything. Our team literally just got lucky - maybe the other team robots didn't work, or the ball hit at the wrong angle, etc etc...

Overall, I'm pretty sure I got 100% in everything, but coming 2nd place in the final competition gave our team an A. I am very happy, but I do not imagine the same can be said for everyone.
reviews.comment_workload:
The work you do, and the effort you put in, does not mean you will get a good grade. Unfortunately, that will most likely always be the case in such a competitive course, especially true for us since we had a football match. Teams that had super cool kicking mechanisms, using clever ways to implement things like actuators, motors and whatnot, 3d printing parts to join it all together, only to come last??

I, and some others, spent several nights, especially leading up to the build demo and final competition working in the lab until up to 4am. The lab is usually open at this time, which saved many teams.

Also, despite having a team of 5, I am giving you a 100% guarantee that we could have done just as well, if not better, with just 3. Some team members did absolutely nothing, partially because there WAS nothing to do... We split the robot building into coding, 3d design and electronics, and they didn't really do anything so... ??? I hope you're a hard worker and don't piggyback your team if you do take this course.
